question: Majority of flowering plants use a range of ______ as pollinating agents.
Bees, butterflies, flies, beetles, wasps, ants, moths, birds (sunbirds and humming birds) and bats are the common ______ agents.
Among the animals, insects, particularly ______ are the dominant biotic pollinating agents.
Even larger animals such as some primates (lemurs), arboreal rodents, or even reptiles like ______ have been reported as pollinators in some species.
Often flowers of animal-pollinated plants are specifically adapted for a particular ______ of animal.
Majority of insect-pollinated flowers are large, colourful, fragrant and rich in ______.
When the flowers are small, a number of flowers are clustered into an ______ to make them conspicuous.
Animals are attracted to flowers by colour and/or ______.
The flowers pollinated by flies and beetles secrete ______ odours to attract these animals.
To sustain animal visits, the flowers have to provide ______ to the animals.
Nectar and ______ grains are the usual floral rewards.
For harvesting the rewards from the flower the animal visitor comes in contact with the ______ and the stigma.
The body of the animal gets a coating of pollen grains, which are generally ______ in animal pollinated flowers.
When the animal carrying pollen on its body comes in contact with the ______, it brings about pollination.
In some species floral rewards are in providing safe places to lay ______.
An example is that of the tallest flower of ______ which is about 6 feet in height.
A similar relationship exists between a species of moth and the plant ______ where both species cannot complete their life cycles without each other.
